[SYNTAX]: Abrupt, unconnected quote ("Y-yes...") with modern terminology ("Vegan", "Irwadi City") disrupts archaic tone and flow.
[LEXICON]: Archaisms ("bewigged", "gadding", "fopperies") may impede modern readability despite intentional stylistic choice.

[LOGIC]: Sudden, unrelated quote ("Y-yes...") breaks historical narrative continuity.
[STRUCTURE]: Mild disjoint between descriptive passages and biographical events, though chapters provide some cohesion.

[SYNTAX]: Complex, archaic sentence structures causing slight awkwardness.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated paragraphs (e.g., wedding customs, political events) disrupting narrative flow.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences (e.g., "He had many qualities...") may slightly impede smooth flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unrelated paragraph about Confederate attack disrupts narrative continuity.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally long, complex sentence structures (e.g., "He was engaged upon the business...")
[LEXICON]: Archaisms ("the light one," "light-o'-love") may slightly impede modern readability

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unconnected shifts between historical events, artistic descriptions, and unrelated quotes (e.g., ancient letter excerpt)
[TRANSITION]: Lack of logical bridges between paragraphs (e.g., Confederate attack to Fragonard’s patrons)

[LEXICON]: Archaisms ("massy") and poetic phrasing ("swinging heavens") may cause minor readability issues.
Ambiguous terms ("homeliest pictures" implies unattractiveness, not domesticity).
[SYNTAX]: Long, comma-less lists (e.g., "truth of their character-drawing...") disrupt flow.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shift from Fragonard’s art to political events (Du Barry/Choiseul) without transitional links.
[TRANSITION]: Sudden introduction of historical context ("royal France on its downward rushing") disrupts narrative cohesion.

[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures (e.g., multiple nested clauses)
[LEXICON]: Occasionally archaic or formal vocabulary (e.g., "wondrous full," "scarcely witless enough")

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from political context to Fragonard’s biography without clear connection
[CLARITY]: Assumes prior knowledge of figures (e.g., Fragonard, Bergeret) and their relevance to the narrative

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing (e.g., "the thunderclap of this 14th of July 1789").
[LEXICON]: Informal tone in formal context (e.g., "got abroad").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt, unconnected philosophical tangent on "unity" disrupting narrative flow.
[TRANSITION]: No clear link between historical events and Fragonard’s personal story in some segments.

[LEXICON]: Occasionally poetic phrasing (e.g., "the breath out of his career") may slightly disrupt natural flow for some readers.
[SYNTAX]: Repetitive rhetorical questions ("what did Fragonard know...") could feel stylistically jarring.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Napoleon’s rise to Fragonard’s return to Paris (e.g., "To Paris Fragonard crept back...") lacks explicit connective tissue.
[STRUCTURE]: Sudden narrative leap to Fragonard’s death ("The move...prelude to a longer journey") feels slightly disconnected from preceding historical context.

[SYNTAX]: Occasional overly complex sentence structures (e.g., "His is the last word...").

[STRUCTURE]: Minor disjointedness between paragraphs (e.g., jump from "peacefully ended" to "Painting with prodigal hand").
